document.text: Mr. A. H. Clement desires it to be understood that he is in the can vass and will endeavor to visit the homes of the people of the county, but that he has been interfered with n some respects by unforeseen cir cumstances. The Baptist ministers of the Ap pomattox Association will meet to day to discuss the needs of the field ind to arrange a tentative program for the Association which meets at Charlotte C. H., August 18. Rev. Hugh Smith attends from this place. Capt. R. S. Echols, who was so badly injured by the wreck between Petersburg and Richmond last Fri day and who was reported to have been killed, is now here on a fair way to permanent recovery. Engi neer Covington and Fireman Cov ington, of the ill-fated train, were killed. All of these gentlemen were well and favorably known in this, county. The following officers qualified on Monday before Judge Christian in the county court, their terms being extended to January 1,1904, under the new Constitutiou S. P. Coleman, sheriff Leon. E. Smith, commissioner of revenue J. W. Paris, superintendent of poor J. R. Horsley, county surveyor W. H. Ligon, J. C. Jones, supervisors. R. F. Burke qualified as treasurer, vice l. Mott Robertson, resigned. It is rumored that T. J. Stratton will stand for road Commissioner in Stonewall, J. F. Dickerson for Gloyer Hill, and Hon. J. C. Jones- and Saml Lee has announced them selves candidates in Southside. No candidate has come out for Super visor for Stonewall, and Hon. W. Hi Ligon has no opposition in Clovef Hill for his old place on the board. Messrs. J. H. Robertson and Ed ward Harvey are candidates for Supervisor from Southside. Quite a surprise was sprung on the village yesterday when Mr. W. D. Cofer, came down from Blue field, W. Va., and secured a license for the marriage of Miss Lizzie Fleshman, which happy event will be celebrated to-day at the home of the brides father in a quiet way. The brides pastor Rev. Hugh C. Smith will officiate. The couple will leave on the evening train for a trip east and will be permanently located in Bluelield, where the groom holds a lucrative position with the N.  W. Ry. Co. Suit was instituted in Richmond by Bollock  Lamb in behalf of Millie C. Cook, who asks 30,000. damages from Alexander Tompkins and others. The plaintiff sets forth that she paid the defendants 103 for a room lor life ir he house at 9115 North Sixthstreet !t is contended that she was denied admission to the room at night, hav- i!g to remain out in the weather and mitered front cold. Dr. F. S. Goodman, steward in the L. S. -hospital service, Norfolk, will per mit  malanal mosquitoes to bite him 1 the interests of science. He wishes Jo see whether one bitten by them wiil be inoculated with malaria Dr. Good man believes he is immune from vellow fever. Ih c Lynchburg City Council author ized the Water Committee to expend fyooo for the purchase of land for the dam site and watershed for the pro posed gravity water supply. The Coun cil also authorized a joint committee to piace the public school buildings in a thorough sanitary condition, a work that will cost about 8000. Samuel Dennis, while at work on the bridge which is being erected across the Rappahannock river at Rem ington, .was killed by being caught under a heavy beam, the rope by which it was suspended having broken. After five attempts to commit sui cide Mrs. Jas. Smith, of Staunton, 41 years old. succeeded in ending her life by strangling. Mrs. Smith came-Ac Staunton several weeks ago from Mil lers School to spend the summer fot her health, and she made three unsuc cessful attempts to throw herself ir front of the Staunton street cars. Last Friday she was taken to the Western State Hospital, where several days age she tried to choke herself with a cord. Thursday after dinner she succeeded in slipping away from the guards, ran into a room and tied a handkerchief around her neck, the other end of which I she tied to a window guard, and threw herself forward, strangling to death. She was in the infirmary ward and a close watch had been kept on her evet since she had been confined in the hos pital. 1 his ward has more guards and is the closest guarded ward in the hos pital. Hers was a case of stticida mania, and in such cases patients art under strict guard. At the coroners inquest no blame was attached to tfiv authorities. William Coulter andhis sweetheart went to the Court Clerks office at W il liamson to secure a marriage license. I he document was written by the clerk and Coulter laid down a half-dol lar, evidently believing that to be the fee. When informed that it required ffiai much more he was not able to pro duce it and asked the young woman if she could advance the amount. She be came enraged and refused to marry hint. They left the office quarreling, and upon reaching the street Coulter became enraged and fiercely attacked his companion, beating her unmerci fully. He was arrested and lodged in jail. Next morning when Jailer Thom as took Coulters breakfast to him he was found dead on the stone floor of the cell. He had been dead several hours when discovered. Judge A. A. Phlegar, late of the Su preme Court of Virginia, has announc ed himself a candidate for the State Senate f-om the Fourth district. Sena tor Lyle, the present Senator, for busi ness reasons will retire. Judge Phle gar was for years the general attorney of the Virginia Iron. Coal and Coke Company. He was later general mana ger, and retired recently to resume the practice of law. Edward C. Carty and his cousin, Maggid Carty, the latter a pretty giri of 18 years old, eloped from Castle- wood. Russell county. They traveled all night, crossing the mountains in an open wagon and arriving in Bristol at 4 oclock in the morning. They were married and started for home as they came. R. C. Stearns, of Salem, announced his candidacy to represent his district in the State Senate of Virginia, subject I to the Democratic nominating pri- j niary. A barn belonging to D. E. Kefauvcr. She was 1 daugh ter of the late Dr. T. B. Johnston, ol Kentucky. The body was shipped tc Memphis. Late Saturday evening, while driving from Pamlin Depot to his farm, Otis Gilliam, a young farmer, of Lynchburg was shot in the head by a spent bullet which came from no one knows where No report of a gun was heard and nc one was in sight with a weapon. Mr Gilliam was not seriously hurt. Mack Fletcher was killed by a fa! from a- window at the liomc of Mr. O A. Eubank, near Round Hill, Loudour county. He has purchased the farm of Mr. George VV. Garratt. which lies adjacent to this place. Mr. Geo. W. G arratt and family have removed from their home here to some plaee in Pennsylvania. Mr. Robert Smith, of this neigh borhood, and Miss Josie G arratt, of this place, were m arried last week Rev. W. E. G rant officiating. We hope for the parties much happiness in their m arried life. Our Mr. Jefferson Davis returned last week from New York. Mrs. H. M. White, accompanied by her sou W ilbur, left last v.eek to spend some weeks- visiting relatives and friends at W arreuton, Va. We wish her a pleasant visit and a sate return. Mrs. Wm, R. Silvey is this week visiting her relatives near Rival, Va. Miss Susie Harden, of this place, is visiting friends at Gravel Hill. Mrs. Willie A. Moss is visiting her relatives at Mt. Viuco. On her return, we think, our friend Willie will have everything ready here foi housekeeping. We are glad to have them with us. document.text: The office of Commissioner of the Revenue for Appomattox county promises tc be a much coveted plum whenever it is pulled off. The candidates for the Democratic nomination will probably be Mr. H. C. Babcock, who came very near the goal at the last election when he was defeated by Mr. L. E. Smith on. S. C. Stratton, Mr. John W. Overton, deputy collector of taxes Mr. Rag-  land Feathers tone, school trustee. It is by no means certain that there will not be other candidates. The nomination for this office may occur at the time of holding the Congressional primary and the election on 2d Tuesday in November, 1903. The disposition of the con stitution makes things a little uncer tain. In the meantime gentlemen your formal announcement cards should appear in the T im es .

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. document.text: Supervisors a n d county of ficials of Appomattox county met at the court house Tues-  day night of this week and agreed to a slashing of the county tax rate and salaries.j The tax-rate will be cut t 1.50 and salaries will be - duced 10 per cent, it fit. agreed. The present i levies run from 1.80 to 1.95. The reduction is expected to cause a bolstering of confidence locally and will be warmly wel comed by tax payers. No con certed demand for a reduction had been made by citizens, but the supervisors and county of f a l s felt that the cut was in .ine with steps already taken by several other counties. The supervisors also felt it best to act in advance of widespread dissatisfaction that might be forthcoming if theratewere not . educed and wisely averted any m a s s meetings of tax payers such as a number of other coun ies have experienced. Th i s act is expected to renew confi dence in the administration of county affairs, and cooperation -vill now be sought in an effort -o avoid drastic cut in upkeep jf roads and the conduct of the jchools. The- statement signed by county supervisors, follows To T h e Taxpayers of Appo mattox Count Realizing the financial con dition of the farmers and citi zens of our county, brought about by the drought of last year, a n d the unprecedented depression whichwe are pass ing, and small demand and low prices for all farm products, and while all of us now receive the lowest salary and compen sation allowed by state laws, but desiring to help relieve the tax burden of o u r people to some extent, hereby express cur willingness and voluntarily agree to accept a ten per cent cut in salary or compensation for the year beginning January 1st, 1932, and pledge ourselves to do everything possible to practice economy in the admin istration of the county affairs, so that the county, school and road levy m a y be reduced to the lowest possible figure. The above ten per cent does not ap ply to the County Treasurer or the Commissioner of the Rev enue, as the reduction in levy automatically reduces their compensation more than ten per cent. C. W. Smith, Clerk R. L. Burke, County Treasurer Jo el W. Flood, Commonwealth Attorney H. W. McKinney, Sheriff J. H. OBrien, Comr. of Revenue J. A. Burke, Supt, of Schools F. A. OBrien, Supervisor Don Moses, Super visor T. E. Owen, Supervisor E. LeRoy Smith, Chairman School Board ,T. J. Ligon, Member School Board j  o! Davidson, Member School Board. ,, 111 viw of the, foregoing, we iu undersififned members of th e Board of Supervisors, whose duty it is to make up the bud get and fix the levy bf the coun ty, desire to state that we wish to do everything we can to low- er the tax rate to t h e lowest possible figure, consistent with sound financing and safeguard ing the institutions of our coun ty. We are sure we can make a substantial reduction in the levy for th e next fiscal year, and agree to make the total levy 1.50 on the 100.00 for all purposes, thus reducing the taxes of the people approxi mately 12,450.00. We real ize this means a substantial cut in county affairs, road building, and length of school term. This includes a reduction in the sal aries and wages of everyone employed by the county, but we feel that an emergency exists , Continued on Page 4
